learning_objectives: Understand the difference between Earth's rotation and revolution
Visualize how Earth's rotation causes day and night
Explain how Earth's revolution and tilted axis cause seasons
Identify the Earth's axis and orbit in a visual model
Apply knowledge to predict seasonal changes in different hemispheres
key_concepts: Earth's rotation on its axis (24 hours)
Earth's revolution around the Sun (365.25 days)
Seasonal changes due to axial tilt and revolution
variables_to_simulate: Earth revolution position (0-360 degrees around Sun)
user_interactions: Slider to control Earth's rotation speed
Slider to position Earth in its orbit around Sun
Slider to adjust Earth's axis tilt angle
Button to toggle between day/night view and seasons view
Button to reset to default values
simulation_logic: Initialize Earth at default position with 23.5-degree tilt
Display Sun at center of screen with Earth in orbit
As rotation slider changes, update Earth's spin animation and day/night terminator line
As revolution slider changes, move Earth along elliptical orbit path
As tilt slider changes, rotate Earth's axis and update sunlight angle on surface
Toggle button switches between: 1) Day/night view showing rotation effects, 2) Seasons view showing hemisphere temperature changes
Play/pause animates Earth's natural rotation and revolution speeds
Reset button returns all controls to default values
mobile_ui_plan: Top section: Large circular view showing Sun and Earth's orbit
Middle section: Detailed Earth view with day/night shading and axis line
Bottom section: Control panel with sliders and buttons in vertical stack
Header: Clear title and brief instruction text
Footer: Key takeaway messages that update based on current settings
misconceptions_to_address: Earth is closer to Sun in summer (actually distance varies but isn't the main cause)
Rotation causes seasons (actually it's revolution + tilt)
Day and night are caused by the Sun moving around Earth
The Earth's orbit is a perfect circle
Both hemispheres experience the same season at the same time
text_instructions_for_students: Welcome! This simulation shows how Earth moves and why we have day/night and seasons.
Use the sliders to explore: 1) How Earth spins (rotation), 2) How Earth orbits the Sun (revolution), 3) How Earth's tilt affects seasons.
Try this: Set Earth to different positions around the Sun and see how the tilt changes which hemisphere gets more sunlight.
Notice: When one hemisphere has summer, the other has winter because of the tilt!
Experiment: Change the rotation speed to see how it affects day and night length.
Remember: Day and night happen because Earth spins, while seasons happen because Earth orbits the Sun AND is tilted!
